The Related Discourses

13. The Noble Path

9. Deathlessness (2)

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

It was then that the Buddha addressed the monks, “There’s what’s called ‘deathlessness.’ What is called ‘deathlessness’? Deathlessness is a description of an element, but I take it to be the end of the contaminants. That’s a clear explanation of this name.”

The monks asked the Buddha, “Bhagavān, isn’t there a path and steps that attain deathlessness when they are cultivated and cultivated often?”

The Buddha told the monks, “There is. It’s known as the noble eightfold path, which is right view up to right concentration.”

After the Buddha had taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. This sutra is reconstituted from a description of variants found after SA 13.7. It’s a variant of SA 13.6 in which the Buddha questions the monks rather than being asked a question. It’s also parallel to SN 45.7.
Translator: Charles Patton
